summary: J. C. King, as Chief of the Western Hemisphere Division of the CIA from approximately 1958 to 1972, played a central role in overseeing and coordinating a wide range of operations and intelligence activities related to Cuba and Latin America. These activities included FI-CI operations, propaganda efforts, political action, paramilitary activities, training, communications, and support. He was responsible for disseminating information, approving operations such as Project LIANCHOR and KDAFGHAN, managing covert operations, and maintaining liaison with foreign intelligence services like the Venezuelan SIFA. King also handled sensitive matters related to individuals such as Luis Clemente Posada Carriles and Alberto PONZOA y Alvarez, and was involved in planning related to Khrushchev's visit to Cuba and a conversation between President Lopez Mateos of Mexico and Winston Scott, Chief of Station, Mexico.
key_connections: Winston Scott, Chief of Station, Mexico
significance: High. J. C. King, as Chief of the Western Hemisphere Division, was a key figure in CIA operations related to Cuba and Latin America during a critical period. The number of documents (11) and the nature of the operations he oversaw suggest a significant role in the agency's activities during this time.
merged_from_variants: J. C. King, Chief, Western Hemisphere Division
